\#\#\# User: I've so far learned about boolean algebra and its applications to transistors. This is a picture of a NAND diagram:

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/fp4lE.png)

A NAND has this boolean property : \\$ f(A,B) \= \\overline{A \\cap B}\\$. What I want to know is how the current is flowing (increasing/decreasing) and the voltages across the collectors. For example, lets say a voltage is applied to A but not to B, then the output which is a load lights up. From my understanding, you need a high enough voltage applied to the base of of a transistor to turn it on and once the base is saturated, you'll have enough current flowing from the collector to emitter. The current on the collector decreases which should mean a low voltage reading on the collector, but this transistor is connected to another transistor. Why is B turned off creating this reading across the resistor? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If B is turned off then its collector is effectively open circuit and there is nowhere for A's Base\-Emitter current to go, so it cannot turn on. 

With both A and B turned off there is no current flow through the resistor, so output voltage equals Vcc.

40.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a NAND gate circuit using two transistors as shown in the image, what happens to the output voltage when input A is high (1) and input B is low (0)?

A) The output voltage drops to near 0V because both transistors conduct.
B) The output voltage remains high (near Vcc) because transistor B blocks current flow.
C) The output voltage fluctuates rapidly between high and low states.
D) The output voltage becomes exactly half of Vcc due to voltage division.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: When input A is high and B is low, transistor A has a voltage applied to its base, but transistor B does not. Since the transistors are connected in series, both need to conduct for the output to be pulled low. With B turned off, its collector is effectively an open circuit, preventing current flow through both transistors. This means there's no current through the pull-up resistor, keeping the output voltage high (near Vcc). This behavior is consistent with the NAND gate's logic, where the output is low only when both inputs are high.

\#\#\# User: I have imported an Intex salt system for use on a locally purchased intex pool. when I received it , the plug is a GFCI plug with a test and reset button on it. the pump is a 230w pump. I purchased a 1000w step down transformer that appears to have a 3 wire configuration.

Still no power. Do I need a specific GFCI outlet or something? Excuse my ignorance.

Thanks
Martin

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: For future readers:

NO: US motors are 60Hz, while NZ are 50Hz (your new pump will run 27% slower). Even if you transform the voltage, that will not ensure that other electronics work as designed.

41.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: An individual has imported a US-manufactured Intex salt system with a 230W pump for use with a locally purchased pool in New Zealand. After connecting the system using a 1000W step-down transformer, they are unable to get it working. What is the most likely reason for this issue?

A) The step-down transformer is not powerful enough for the pump
B) A GFCI outlet is required for the system to function properly
C) The frequency difference between US and NZ power systems is causing the problem
D) The wiring configuration of the transformer is incompatible with the pump

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The primary issue here is the difference in electrical frequency between the United States (60Hz) and New Zealand (50Hz) power systems. Even though the voltage can be adjusted using a step-down transformer, this does not address the frequency mismatch. As a result, the US-designed pump, which is meant to operate at 60Hz, will run approximately 27% slower when connected to the 50Hz power supply in New Zealand. This frequency difference can affect not only the pump's performance but also other electronic components in the salt system, potentially causing them to malfunction or not work at all. The voltage transformation alone is insufficient to ensure proper operation of equipment designed for a different frequency.

\#\#\# User: ArcGIS Pro 2\.1 does not allow saving / exporting of a model constructed with ModelBuilder as a Python script.

It seems that the only way we can circumvent this limitation is to click on each individual geoprocessing history item, but, it is not very efficient to do so.

Is there another workaround?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: My original answer appears below the double line. I am updating it because when I checked ArcGIS Pro 2\.7\.2 just now it looks like the functionality that you seek has been returned at that or an earlier version. It can be found on the ModelBuilder tab of the Ribbon under Export \| Export To Python File.

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/9SSLr.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/9SSLr.png)

---

---

The reasons for the removal of this functionality are given at [What happened To Export Script Button In ArcGIS Pro?](https://community.esri.com/thread/163291) by dflater\-esristaff:

> The ability to export from ModelBuilder to a Python script was removed
> from ArcGIS Pro 1\.1 because it did not match user expectations to
> provide a one\-to\-one export of your model to Python. The scripts
> generated by exported models were missing nested sub\-models, and did
> not include iterators, feedback loops, and in\-line variable
> substitution. Models with these components would require major changes
> that most people who use Export are not able to make themselves. There
> is currently no plan to add this capability back into ArcGIS Pro.

I ceased exporting ModelBuilder models in ArcMap to Python code the day I discovered Copy As Python Snippet because the exported code was far harder to understand and debug due to the way it named variables, lacked understanding of iterators, etc.

I think it is far easier to learn ArcPy in ArcGIS Pro by using Copy Python Command to copy the exact Python syntax needed to run the geoprocessing tool with the same parameter settings previously used, and then paste it into a script that you are writing.

Alternatively, if you want to quickly run your model using ArcPy, dflater\-esristaff also describes a workaround of:

> Start by building and saving a model, then create a new Python script
> file (which is just a text file with .py extension), then using a text
> editor or Python IDE add lines to the new script to import arcpy,
> import the toolbox containing your model, and finally run the model.
> 
> 
> ...
> 
> 
> 
> ```
> import arcpy
> arcpy.ImportToolbox(r"c:\pathtotbx\Toolbox.tbx", "mytools")
> arcpy.MyModel_mytools(r"c:\modelinputs\Data.gdb\InputFeatures")
> 
> ```

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You've created a complex model in ArcGIS Pro 2.7.2 using ModelBuilder and now want to convert it to a Python script. Which of the following statements is true regarding this process?

A) You must click on each individual geoprocessing history item to recreate the model as a Python script.

B) The functionality to export a model to a Python script was removed in ArcGIS Pro 1.1 and has not been reintroduced in later versions.

C) You can export the model to a Python script using the "Export To Python File" option under the Export menu on the ModelBuilder tab of the Ribbon.

D) The only way to run your model using ArcPy is to manually create a new Python script file and import the toolbox containing your model.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. As of ArcGIS Pro 2.7.2, the functionality to export a ModelBuilder model to a Python script has been reintroduced. This can be done using the "Export To Python File" option under the Export menu on the ModelBuilder tab of the Ribbon.

Option A is incorrect because while this was a workaround in earlier versions, it's no longer necessary with the reintroduction of the export functionality.

Option B is outdated information. While the export functionality was indeed removed in ArcGIS Pro 1.1, it has since been reintroduced in later versions.

Option D describes a valid alternative method to run a model using ArcPy, but it's not the only or most efficient way given the reintroduction of the export functionality. Therefore, this option is not the best answer to the question posed.

\#\#\# User: Example:
Product A: SKU\# 15
Product B: SKU\# 18

Now on the front end of our website, Product A would show up first because the SKU number is lower than Product B.

Is there any way to get Product B to show up first without making its SKU number lower than Product A's?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Go to `Catalog -> Categories -> Manage Categories`. 

Under the *Display Settings* tab, select the *Default Product Listing Sort By* to "Best Value". 

Under the *Category Products* tab, set the position of your products. 

Save your category and re\-index.

B) Go to Catalog -> Categories -> Manage Categories, select "Best Value" under Default Product Listing Sort By in the Display Settings tab, set product positions in the Category Products tab, save the category, and re-index

D) Go to Catalog -> Attributes -> Manage Attributes, create a new attribute called "Display Order", assign values to products, and sort by this attribute

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct sequence of steps is outlined in option B. This method allows the store manager to control the order of products within a category without changing SKU numbers. By setting the Default Product Listing Sort By to "Best Value" and then manually setting product positions, the manager can achieve custom ordering. The final step of re-indexing ensures that the changes take effect on the front-end of the website. Options A, C, and D either use incorrect navigation paths, suggest methods that aren't mentioned in the original documentation, or wouldn't achieve the desired result without changing SKU numbers.

\#\#\# User: I have a `.pid` file, and I need to check if the process is running. So far I found two options

```
kill -0 `cat something.pid`

```

which prints out an error if the pid isn't running. I know this can be redirected to `/dev/null`, but it makes me think that this isn't the best solution.

The second solution would be to use `ps`, which however also prints on the STDOUT

```
ps -ef `cat something.pid`

```

Is it normal to redirect the output to `/dev/null` and just use the status code returned, or is it a sign that I'm doing something wrong and I need a different command?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: for most linux distros enumerating the /proc/{pid} is a good way to obtain information about the running processes, and usually how the userspace commands like "ps" are communicating with the kernel. So for example you can do;

```
[ -d "/proc/${kpid}" ] && echo "process exists" || echo "process not exists"

```

Edit: you should check that kpid is set, but this is more useful as it will return "not exists" for unset ${kpid}

```
[ -n "${kpid}" -a -d "/proc/${kpid}" ] && echo "process exists" || echo "process not exists"

```

45.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following methods is considered the most efficient and reliable way to check if a process with a known PID is running on most Linux distributions?

A) Using the kill command: kill -0 `cat process.pid`

B) Using the ps command: ps -ef `cat process.pid`

C) Checking the /proc directory: [ -d "/proc/${pid}" ]

D) Using the top command: top -p `cat process.pid`

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the most efficient and reliable method for checking if a process is running on most Linux distributions. This approach directly checks the /proc filesystem, which is a virtual filesystem that provides information about running processes.

A) While the kill -0 command can be used to check if a process exists, it's not the most efficient method and may require redirecting error output.

B) The ps command works but it produces output on stdout, which may need to be redirected. It's also less efficient than directly checking the /proc filesystem.

C) Checking for the existence of a directory in /proc/${pid} is a direct and efficient way to determine if a process is running. The /proc filesystem is maintained by the kernel and provides real-time information about processes.

D) While the top command can show information about a specific process, it's primarily designed for interactive use and monitoring system resources, not for efficiently checking if a single process is running.

The /proc method (option C) is preferred because it's fast, doesn't produce unnecessary output, and directly interfaces with the kernel's process information.

\#\#\# User: What is the simplest way of generating 42\.8 \[MHz] square (or sine) wave? I want to clock fast ADC for SDR purposes. I thought about wideband opamp and 10\.7 \[Mhz] cystal 4th harmonic. Is there any other solution?

Edit:
I did search for specialized ic's but without success. I am looking for one piece device available for hobbyist. I live in EU and I don't want to import.

Edit2:
For more clearance:

1. Simple solution: power in, clock out
2. Constant frequency
3. Reasonable stability (for radio purposes)
4. PLL is an alternative
5. If you want to recommend device please do it only if it's available in mayor European retail distributor.
6. Most companies do not send samples to Poland (unless you are a company which I am not) so samples are out of option :(

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Have you seen this chip from Texas Instruments?

> <http://www.ti.com/product/cdcs502>

The CDCS502 is a crystal clock generator with built\-in 4x clock multiplier.

The same 10\.7 MHz crystal you mentioned above, plus one of these, will give you a nice stable 42\.8MHz clock signal.

It also does spread\-spectrum as an added bonus should that interest you at all.

46.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An engineer is designing a Software Defined Radio (SDR) system and needs to generate a 42.8 MHz clock signal for a fast ADC. Which of the following solutions best meets the criteria of simplicity, constant frequency, reasonable stability, and availability in the European market?

A) Use a wideband op-amp with a 10.7 MHz crystal to generate the 4th harmonic
B) Implement a Phase-Locked Loop (PLL) circuit using discrete components
C) Utilize the Texas Instruments CDCS502 crystal clock generator with a 10.7 MHz crystal
D) Design a custom oscillator circuit using a specialized 42.8 MHz crystal

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) While using a wideband op-amp with a 10.7 MHz crystal to generate the 4th harmonic could work, it may not provide the best stability and simplicity compared to other options.

B) Implementing a PLL circuit using discrete components could achieve the desired frequency, but it would be more complex and potentially less stable than an integrated solution.

C) The Texas Instruments CDCS502 crystal clock generator with a 10.7 MHz crystal is the best solution as it meets all the criteria. It's a simple one-chip solution that provides a constant frequency output, offers reasonable stability for radio purposes, and is likely available from major European distributors. The built-in 4x clock multiplier allows it to generate 42.8 MHz from a 10.7 MHz crystal input.

D) Designing a custom oscillator circuit with a specialized 42.8 MHz crystal would be unnecessarily complex and may face availability issues in the European market.

The correct answer (C) provides the simplest and most effective solution that meets all the specified requirements.

\#\#\# User: I simply want to get rid of all non critical Microsoft programs from Windows 10\.

They've made it incredibly difficult to permanently kill Defender and One Drive. Even after they are removed, you'll still get Ads.

There must be a script or tool to ease the suffering that comes with a new Windows 10 install.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **Update 2018: These break semi frequently as [MS has been neutering Group Policies](https://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/3010547/microsoft-says-its-best-not-to-fiddle-with-windows-10-enterprise-group-policies) let me know in comments if something's broken or submit edits**

As no program like that exists, here are the steps for everything you need. This will result in a quite clean Windows 10 Pro, without OneDrive, Defender, Candy Crush, Bing or annoying security warnings. The key is to master windows Group Policies. Some of these require windows Enterprise edition, but there are registry hacks that may achieve the same result.

Cortana Taskbar Search
======================

You can remove the bar by right clicking it and selecting hidden.

Change default search engine on Edge Browser
============================================

1. Go to Google.com.
2. click on the browser settings
3. click Advanced Settings
4. Click "Change search engine". For some inexplicable reason this takes a while... not the case in every other browser.

Disable Bing search on Start Menu
=================================

It is no longer possible to change the search engine in the start menu search bar: 
[http://www.theverge.com/2016/4/28/11532474/windows\-10\-block\-google\-search\-cortana\-bing\-edge](http://www.theverge.com/2016/4/28/11532474/windows-10-block-google-search-cortana-bing-edge)
The best we can do is disable web search in it.

1. open the Local Group Policy Editor. You can run it by searching "edit group policy" in the start menu.
2. Go to "Local Computer Policy\\Computer Configuration\\Administrative Templates\\Windows Components\\Search"
3. Enable "Do not allow web search"
4. Disable "Allow Cortana"

Disable OneDrive and remove it from File Explorer
=================================================

1. Run uninstall on it normally and close all instances of file explorer.
	* Other option: <https://superuser.com/a/1033668/40974>

Disable Windows Defender
========================

1. open the Local Group Policy Editor. You can run it by searching "edit group policy" in the start menu.
2. Go to "Local Computer Policy\\Computer Configuration\\Administrative Templates\\Windows Components\\Windows Defender"
3. Enable the "Turn off Windows Defender Policy"
4. Click the no AV alert
5. Click "Turn Off notifications about A.V."

Remove and prevent Candy Crush and other Windows Store spam from installing
===========================================================================

[http://winaero.com/blog/fix\-windows\-10\-installs\-apps\-like\-candy\-crush\-soda\-saga\-automatically/](http://winaero.com/blog/fix-windows-10-installs-apps-like-candy-crush-soda-saga-automatically/)

1. open the Local Group Policy Editor. You can run it by searching "edit group policy" in the start menu.
2. Go to "Local Computer Policy\\Computer Configuration\\Administrative Templates\\Windows Components\\ConsumerContent"
3. Enable the "Turn off Consumer Content"

Uninstall People, Food, Messaging etc:
======================================

[https://windows.gadgethacks.com/how\-to/goodbye\-bloatware\-remove\-all\-preinstalled\-crapware\-from\-window\-10\-0164605/](https://windows.gadgethacks.com/how-to/goodbye-bloatware-remove-all-preinstalled-crapware-from-window-10-0164605/)

Disable ads from Windows 10 lock screen
=======================================

[https://www.howtogeek.com/243263/how\-to\-disable\-ads\-on\-your\-windows\-10\-lock\-screen/](https://www.howtogeek.com/243263/how-to-disable-ads-on-your-windows-10-lock-screen/)

1. Go to "Start \-\> Settings \-\> Personalisation \-\> lock screen"
2. Set the lockscreen to picture or slideshow, NOT Windows Spotlight
3. Disable "Get fun facts, tips, tricks **and more** on your lockscreen"

Finishing touches
=================

1. Restart.
2. Optionally, run the [https://github.com/W4RH4WK/Debloat\-Windows\-10](https://github.com/W4RH4WK/Debloat-Windows-10) scripts, they make very robust global changes that prevent spam from coming back, even for new users!

Bonus for Windows 10 Basic users (no GPEdit)
============================================

* [How to Disable onedrive on Windows 10 Basic](https://appuals.com/how-to-disable-onedrive-windows-10/)

TODO

1. Way to globally nuke windows store. [http://www.urtech.ca/2015/09/solved\-how\-to\-disable\-the\-store\-app\-in\-windows\-10/](http://www.urtech.ca/2015/09/solved-how-to-disable-the-store-app-in-windows-10/)

47.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following methods would be most effective for completely removing Microsoft Defender and preventing it from reinstalling on a Windows 10 Pro system?

A) Uninstall Microsoft Defender using the Control Panel and then delete its program files
B) Use the Windows Settings app to turn off real-time protection for Microsoft Defender
C) Modify the Windows Registry to disable Microsoft Defender's services
D) Use Group Policy Editor to enable the "Turn off Windows Defender" policy under Computer Configuration

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because simply uninstalling Defender through normal means is not sufficient to permanently remove it from Windows 10.

Option B is not effective as it only temporarily disables Defender's real-time protection, but doesn't prevent it from re-enabling itself later.

Option C could potentially work, but modifying the registry directly is risky and may not prevent Defender from being re-enabled by Windows updates.

Option D is the most effective method as described in the documentation. Using Group Policy Editor to enable the "Turn off Windows Defender" policy under Computer Configuration > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > Windows Defender will disable Defender system-wide and prevent it from being re-enabled, even after updates. This method is recommended for Windows 10 Pro users who want to permanently disable Defender.

\#\#\# User: How do I install azure CLI on CentOS 6\.6\.

```
python -V -> Python 2.6.6
which python -> /usr/bin/python 

/usr/local/bin/python2.7 -V -> Python 2.7.13

curl -L https://aka.ms/InstallAzureCli | bash  

```

**ERROR: The CLI does not support Python versions less than 2\.7\.**

How do i get the above script to take the python 2\.7 installed.

thanks

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Azure CLI 2\.0 need python 2\.7\. I test in my Centos 6\.8 VM. Python 2\.6 could not upgrade 2\.7\. So, as Khaled said, you need download python 2\.7 and install it.

Please refer to following steps:

```
yum groupinstall "Development tools" ##If you meet error, ignore it
yum install zlib-devel bzip2-devel openssl-devel ncurses-devel sqlite-devel
##download python 2.7 and install it
cd /opt
wget --no-check-certificate https://www.python.org/ftp/python/2.7.6/Python-2.7.6.tar.xz
tar xf Python-2.7.6.tar.xz
cd Python-2.7.6
./configure --prefix=/usr/local
make && make altinstall
##create link
ln -sf /usr/local/bin/python2.7 /usr/local/bin/python

```

Then, you need edit $PATH, add `/usr/local/bin` to `/etc/profile` like below

```
# Path manipulation
if [ "$EUID" = "0" ]; then
    pathmunge /usr/local/bin
    pathmunge /sbin
    pathmunge /usr/sbin
    pathmunge /usr/local/sbin
else

```

Then `source /etc/profile`

Check the result.

```
[root@shui bin]# which python
/usr/local/bin/python

```

More information about this please refer to this [link](https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-2/wiki/installing-python-2.7-on-centos-6.3.-follow-this-sequence-exactly-for-centos-machine-only).

48.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are trying to install Azure CLI on a CentOS 6.6 system, but encounter an error stating "The CLI does not support Python versions less than 2.7." Your system has Python 2.6.6 installed by default, and Python 2.7.13 is available at /usr/local/bin/python2.7. Which of the following sets of steps would correctly allow you to install Azure CLI?

A) Simply run the Azure CLI installation script with Python 2.7:
   /usr/local/bin/python2.7 -c "$(curl -L https://aka.ms/InstallAzureCli)"

B) Update the system's default Python to 2.7 using yum:
   yum update python
   curl -L https://aka.ms/InstallAzureCli | bash

C) Perform the following steps:
   1. Install development tools and necessary libraries
   2. Download and install Python 2.7 from source
   3. Create a symbolic link to the new Python installation
   4. Update the system PATH in /etc/profile
   5. Run the Azure CLI installation script

D) Uninstall Python 2.6 and reinstall Python 2.7 using yum:
   yum remove python
   yum install python27
   curl -L https://aka.ms/InstallAzureCli | bash

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct approach is to install Python 2.7 from source, as CentOS 6.6 doesn't support upgrading to Python 2.7 through the default package manager. Option C outlines the necessary steps to properly install Python 2.7, update the system to use it as the default Python interpreter, and then install Azure CLI. This method ensures that the system has the required Python version without breaking existing dependencies, and allows the Azure CLI installation script to use the correct Python version.

\#\#\# User: On Ubuntu Natty I've got a weird problem using evolution. A coworker (using Outlook) sends me an appointment request. The mail is received in Evolution but the 'Accept' and 'Deny' buttons are greyed out and not clickable. Instead there is a message "searching for an existing version of this appointment" permanently visible.
I have no way of either accept or refuse the appointment.

Any hints?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I got the same problem using evolution 2\.32\.2: I couldn't respond to Outlook invitations because the program waited forever with the message "searching for an existing version of this appointment".

I use a google calendar account as my default calendar, so the solution I found was to delete that calendar, and then add it again (not nice, but the best I could think of).

If you're not able to delete the calendar by right clicking on it (what seems to be another problem with evolution), then you have to open the gconf\-editor, go to /apps/evolution/calendar/sources and delete the entries corresponding to the google calendar.

HTH,
Damian.

\#\#\# User: I'm currently working to adapt the No U\-Turn Sampler from this [paper](http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/published/nuts.pdf) for a model I'm working on.

The No\-U Turn sampler augments the typical hamiltonian system by incorporating a slice variable $u$ such that $p(\\theta,r,u) \\propto I(u \\in \[0,\\exp\\{ \\mathcal{L}(\\theta) \- \\frac{1}{2}r^{T}r\\}]]$, where $\\mathcal{L}(\\theta)$ is the unnormalized log posterior and $r$ are the momentum variables (p.1599 of paper). However, In most trivial model setups I create, any (including the max) exponentiated log likelihood of `double` (or even `long double`) types evaluate to zero. Resulting in a degenerate distribution and consequently, non\-meaningful draws. 

**Goal:** Draw *meaningful* random variates from this distribution.

This suggests I should keep things on the log\-scale. However, even transforming $u$ to, say $z\=\\log(u)$ will result in a distribution that still requires the computation of $exp\\{\\mathcal{L}(\\theta)\\} $ (see below \- only included for justification). I'm looking for any suggestions that will help me accomplish my goal above. Thanks.

$$
a :\=\\exp(\\mathcal{L}(\\theta) \- \\frac{1}{2}r^{T}r)\\\\
f\_U(u) \= \\frac{I(0 \\leq u \\leq a )}{a}\\\\
z :\= \\log (u) \\iff e^z \= u ; \\quad \\mid\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial z}\\mid \= e^{z}\\\\
$$
$$
\\Rightarrow f\_Z(z) \= \\frac{I(\-\\infty \< z \< \\log(a))}{a}e^z \\tag{\*}
$$

Since $a$ is still in the denominator in $f\_Z(z)$ I'll still have problems computing this (as it will persist to the CDF as well).

Much obliged for any insight.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Received the following suggestion from a Computer Science Professor that is able to get $\\log(u)$ without using the CDF method.

1. Draw $z \\sim $ Unif($0,1\)$
2. Compute $\\log(u) \= \\log(z) \+ \\mathcal{L}(\\theta)$

Where step 2 works because of log rules, $\\log(z)\+\\mathcal{L}(\\theta) \= \\log(z\*\\mathcal{L}) \= \\log(u)$

Then use $\\log(u)$ for any comparisons with other values on the log scale.

51.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In implementing the No-U-Turn Sampler (NUTS) algorithm, a researcher encounters numerical issues with computing exp{L(θ) - 1/2r^T r} due to floating-point limitations. To address this, they decide to work on the log scale. Which of the following methods correctly generates log(u) without requiring the explicit computation of the problematic exponential term?

A) Draw z ~ Unif(-∞, L(θ)), then set log(u) = z
B) Draw z ~ Unif(0, 1), then set log(u) = z * L(θ)
C) Draw z ~ Unif(0, 1), then set log(u) = log(z) + L(θ)
D) Draw z ~ Exp(1), then set log(u) = z + L(θ) - 1/2r^T r

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the correct method suggested by the Computer Science Professor. This approach avoids the numerical issues by working entirely on the log scale.

A is incorrect because it doesn't properly account for the uniform distribution on u and incorrectly sets the range for z.

B is incorrect because it uses multiplication instead of addition, which doesn't follow the properties of logarithms.

C is correct. It uses the properties of logarithms: log(u) = log(z * exp(L(θ))) = log(z) + L(θ), where z is uniformly distributed between 0 and 1.

D is incorrect because it uses an exponential distribution for z instead of a uniform distribution, and it unnecessarily includes the r^T r term, which should be handled separately in the NUTS algorithm.

This question tests understanding of both the NUTS algorithm and techniques for avoiding numerical issues in computational statistics.

\#\#\# User: I want to typeset an equation for a paper. In the field of computer science we can define an equation that depends upon the form of one of it's arguments. I want to typeset this with LaTeX \& `amsmath`.

I might write it as follows in a program, I'm using a familiar example:

```
fib 0 = 1
fib 1 = 1
fib X = (fib (X - 1)) + (fib (X - 2))

```

This could be typeset to appear as:

```
fib X = { 1                              if X < 2
        { (fib (X - 1)) + (fib (X - 2))  otherwise

```

And I know how to do this using amsmath's align and case environments. But I'd prefer the pattern match or guards to appear on the left of the equation, the same way they would in the program above. Can someone point me at how I can do this?

This is what I have so far using \\begin{array}{llcl} but the spacing doesn't look right. This is the actual equation I'm trying to typeset, fibs is just a familiar example.

```
$$
\begin{array}{llcl}
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & X = Y &=& 0 \\
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & X = f(\ldots)                &=& 0 \\
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & p(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)        &=& 
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V\,(\operatorname{body}\,p) \\
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & V = \,f(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)  &=&
    \operatorname{prodtime}\,V\,(\operatorname{body}\,f) \\
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & X_0(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)      &=& time\_of\_call \\
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & m(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)        &=& time\_of\_call \\
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & foreign(\ldots)              &=& 0 \\
\operatorname{prodtime}\,V & G_{head},\,G_{tail}
\end{array}
$$

```

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Without an image of exactly how you want this typeset it is difficult to know for sure, but perhaps one of these is what you are looking for:

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/GZtb4.png)

or perhaps:

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/pjYK1.png)

```
\documentclass{book}
\usepackage{amsmath}
\newcommand{\fib}{\mathrm{fib}}

\begin{document}
\begin{align*}
    &\text{if }  x < 2 & \fib X &= 1 \\
    &\text{otherwise } & \fib X &= (\fib (X - 1)) + (\fib (X - 2))
\end{align*}
Another option is:
\begin{align*}
\fib X = \begin{cases}
    \text{if }  x < 2 & = 1 \\
    \text{otherwise } & = (\fib (X - 1)) + (\fib (X - 2))
\end{cases}
\end{align*}
\end{document}

```

---

Here is how you can modify the given MWE to obtain better spacing:

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/GRwJj.png)

Notes:
------

* `@{}` is used to eliminate the inter column spacing
* I added `{}` before the `=` to get proper math spacing.
* I replaced the `$$ ... $$` with `\[ ... \]`. See [Why is \\\[ ... \\] preferable to $$ ... $$?](https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/503/why-is-preferable-to) for more details.
* Changes as per egreg's suggestions:

	1. `\mathit{foreign}`, `\mathit{time\_of\_call}` and `\mathrm{head}` for better appearance of the formulas.
	2. Removed `\,` after `\prodtime`, and the other uses of `\operatorname`.

Code:
-----

```
\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{amsmath}

\newcommand{\prodtime}{\operatorname{prodtime}}

\begin{document}
\[
\begin{array}{l l @{}l}
\prodtime V & X = Y                        &{}= 0 \\
\prodtime V & X = f(\ldots)                &{}= 0 \\
\prodtime V & p(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)        &{}= \prodtime V\,(\operatorname{body} p) \\
\prodtime V & V = \,f(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)  &{}= \prodtime V\,(\operatorname{body} f) \\
\prodtime V & X_0(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)      &{}= \mathit{time\_of\_call} \\
\prodtime V & m(X_1,\,\ldots,\,X_n)        &{}= \mathit{time\_of\_call} \\
\prodtime V & \mathit{foreign}(\ldots)     &{}= 0 \\
\prodtime V & G_\mathrm{head},\,G_\mathrm{tail}
\end{array}
\]
\end{document}

```

\#\#\# User: I'm looking for an antonym for individualistic that ideologically corresponds to valuing the common good above the individual.

For example when Spock says "*the needs of the many outweighs the needs of the few*", what ideological stance could this view be ascribed to? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I think 
[collectivism](http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/collectivism) may convey the concept you are referring to (www.merriam\-webster.com):

> * emphasis on collective rather than individual action or identity
> * Any of several types of **social organization that ascribe central importance to the groups to which individuals belong** (e.g., state, nation, ethnic group, or social class). **It may be contrasted with individualism. Jean\-Jacques Rousseau was the first modern philosopher to discuss it** (1762\). Karl Marx was its most forceful proponent in the 19th century. Communism, fascism, and socialism may all be termed collectivist systems. See also communitarianism; kibbutz; moshav.

[Collectivistic cultures](http://psychology.about.com/od/cindex/fl/What-Are-Collectivistic-Cultures.htm): (www:psychology.about.com)

> * emphasize the needs and goals of the group as a whole over the needs and wishes of each individual. In such cultures, relationships with other members of the group and the interconnectedness between people play a central role in each person's identity. Cultures in Asia, Central America, South America, and Africa tend to be more collectivistic.

53.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In political philosophy, which term best describes an ideology that prioritizes the common good over individual interests, as exemplified by Spock's statement "the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few"?

A) Individualism
B) Libertarianism
C) Collectivism
D) Anarchism

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Collectivism is the correct answer as it emphasizes the importance of group identity and collective action over individual interests. This aligns with the idea of prioritizing the common good, as expressed in Spock's statement.

Individualism (A) is incorrect as it focuses on personal autonomy and self-reliance, which is the opposite of what the question asks.

Libertarianism (B) is incorrect as it advocates for maximum individual liberty and minimal state intervention, which does not prioritize the common good over individual interests.

Anarchism (D) is incorrect as it advocates for the abolition of all forms of hierarchical control, including the state, which doesn't necessarily prioritize the common good in the way described.

Collectivism, as described in the provided information, ascribes central importance to the groups to which individuals belong, such as the state, nation, or social class. This ideology aligns with valuing the needs of the many over the needs of the few or the individual.

\#\#\# User: Does a PC's hardware temperature increase when it is in standby (sleep) mode or is it the same as if the PC is turned off?

If it does increase, can the hardware be damaged?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The heat produced is directly proportional to the energy consumed, as all the energy eventually turns into heat. In sleep mode energy is mainly used for reserving contents of RAM. Depending on the setup, some USB devices may stay on, but external USB devices can be ruled out.

That's more than no energy at all (turned off), but...

Let's imagine a PC in the sleep mode consumes approximately 0,05 amperes from 230 V AC power, which sounds reasonable. That's less than 12 watts. You can easily touch a 12 W LED bulb, and even a small PC has more area than a bulb. The summer condition causes more heat than that, so you should avoid direct sunlight instead of sleep mode.

54.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A computer technician is analyzing the power consumption and heat generation of a PC in different states. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding a PC in sleep mode?

A) The PC generates the same amount of heat as when it's completely turned off, posing no risk to hardware.

B) Sleep mode causes significant heat generation, potentially damaging hardware if left in this state for extended periods.

C) The PC consumes a small amount of power (approximately 12 watts) to maintain RAM contents, generating minimal heat that is unlikely to cause hardware damage.

D) Sleep mode completely cuts off power to all components, including RAM, resulting in zero heat generation.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the documentation, a PC in sleep mode consumes a small amount of power, estimated at around 12 watts, primarily to maintain the contents of RAM. This power consumption results in minimal heat generation, which is significantly less than during normal operation and unlikely to cause any hardware damage. 

Answer A is incorrect because sleep mode does consume some power, unlike when the PC is completely off. 

Answer B overstates the heat generation in sleep mode; the minimal power consumption does not lead to significant heat that could damage hardware. 

Answer D is incorrect because sleep mode specifically maintains power to RAM to preserve its contents, and does not completely cut off power to all components.

\#\#\# User: Researching distributed source control management (specifically mercurial).
My question is more or less **what is the best practice for rejecting entire sets of code that fail testing?**

**Example:**

A team is working on a hello world program. They have testers and a scheduled release coming up with specific features planned. 

```
Upcoming Release:
   Add feature A
   Add feature B
   Add feature C

```

So, the developers make their clones for their features, do the work and merge them into a QA repo for the testers to scrutinize. 

Let's say the testers report back that "Feature B is incomplete and in fact dangerous", and they would like to retest A and C.

![Repo Doodle](https://i.stack.imgur.com/DteiT.png)

**End example.**

What's the best way to do all this so that feature B can easily be removed and you end up with a new repo that contains only feature A and C merged together?

Recreate the test repo? Back out B? Other magic?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The key here is to come up with a workflow that avoids the situation where "bad" code is ever exposed to developers or teams other than those who created it. If this were to occur, good code would be mixed with bad, and "unmerging" or detangling them will be difficult. So, prevent this from happening in the first place.

I'm assuming that HelloWorld in this example is the mainline repository, that contains known good code. Developers A, B, and C all clone from this repo and develop their changes against it. In the model I'm describing, HelloWorld\-test is a transient repo solely used by QA to test merged changes before moving them into the mainline. Developers never look at HelloWorld\-test. Here's how it works.

* A, B, and C all clone good code from mainline (HelloWorld).
* A makes changes and tells QA she's ready (or A pushes her changes to a staging repo). QA clones mainline and pulls and merges A's changes, and then builds and tests. Assuming this is all successful, QA then merges these changes into the mainline.
* B now makes his changes available. QA clones mainline and then pulls and merges B's changes into HelloWorld\-test. Continuing with your example, let's say these changes are bad. So QA's merge fails, or the build fails, or the tests fail, or something. At this point QA declares the changes to be bad, notifies B, and simply throws away HelloWorld\-test. It's now B's responsibility to pull and merge from mainline, fix test failures, or whatever.
* QA can then perform the process with C, starting from a fresh clone of mainline, and merging in C's changes. Note that B's bad changes have never reached the mainline and so C's changes (or anybody else's) will never be mixed with them.
* At some point B has fixed up his changes and asks QA to do another pull/merge/build/test. QA can do this next, or they can just go around the cycle of different developers or teams until they come back to B.

This is often called a "pull model" of development. I believe Linux kernel changes are managed this way.

In many cases it's not "QA" who does the pull/merge/build/test cycle, but instead it's done by a continuous integration system such as Hudson or Jenkins.

Of course, there are many variations of this, whether individual developers or teams have staging repos, whether changes are propagated via pushing or pulling, etc. But they should all share these key characteristics:

1. Only known good changes make it into the mainline.
2. Developers only pull/clone from mainline, thus they never base their work on bad changes.
3. New changes are merged, built, and tested in isolation from everything else and are verified good before being merged into the mainline.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A software development team is using a distributed version control system for their project. They want to implement a workflow that prevents bad code from being exposed to other developers. Which of the following approaches best achieves this goal?

A) Merge all feature branches into a single QA branch, then cherry-pick the good commits into the main branch.

B) Have QA create a new branch for each feature, merge the feature into it, test, and only merge successful features into the main branch.

C) Developers push all changes directly to the main branch, and QA reverts bad commits after testing.

D) QA clones the main branch, pulls and merges each feature separately for testing, and only merges successful features back into the main branch.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option D represents the "pull model" described in the documentation. This approach ensures that:
1. Only known good changes make it into the main branch.
2. Developers always base their work on the known good main branch.
3. New changes are tested in isolation before being merged into the main branch.

Option A could lead to mixing of good and bad code. Option B creates unnecessary branches and doesn't isolate testing. Option C allows bad code to reach the main branch, potentially affecting other developers. Option D correctly implements the workflow that prevents bad code from being exposed to other developers or teams.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Given a set I of N items, where each item is a set of integers, and a function valid_items(I, candidate) that returns the subset of I with non-empty intersections with the candidate set, which of the following statements is true about the optimal data structure for caching the results?

A) A hash table with key-value pairs where keys are individual integers and values are sets of items containing that integer is the most efficient solution.

B) A bit vector representation for items_containing, using bitwise OR operations for merging, significantly improves the big-O time complexity.

C) A 2^N space complexity solution is necessary for optimal performance.

D) A balanced tree structure like a red-black tree would provide better time complexity than the proposed caching method.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: The correct answer is A. The solution described in the documentation, using an array or hash table (items_containing) where each index/key represents an integer and the value is the set of items containing that integer, is indeed an optimal solution in terms of space-time trade-off.

Option B is incorrect because while bit vector representation and bitwise operations can provide micro-optimizations, they don't change the big-O time complexity.

Option C is incorrect as the documentation explicitly states that a 2^N space solution is not acceptable, and it's not necessary for optimal performance.

Option D is incorrect because a balanced tree structure wouldn't provide better time complexity for this specific problem compared to the direct access provided by the array/hash table approach.

The proposed solution with items_containing has a reasonable space complexity (O(N) or O(N log N)) and allows for efficient lookups and unions, making it the optimal choice among the given options.

\#\#\# User: Does anyone know of any result that deals with the following problem of counting the number of solutions of a certain algebraic equation over a finite field?

Let $p$ be an odd prime and $(a,b,c,d)\\in\\mathbb{F}\_p^4$. How many solutions does the following equation have:

$$
ab^2 \+ cd^2 \= bc^2 \+ da^2\.
$$

And more generally, if $1\\le m,n\\le q\-1$ are two integers, how many solutions does the equation 
$$
a^mb^n \+ c^md^n \= b^mc^n \+ d^ma^n
$$
have?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The projectivization of your first equation is a cubic surface which (unless I made a mistake) is smooth for $p\>5$. So the number of solutions of the projectivized equation is of the form $N\=p^2\+\\alpha p \+ \\beta$ where $\\alpha, \\beta$ range over a short finite list of single digit integers. The full list is, I think, in Manin's book "Cubic forms" or in Swinnerton\-Dyer "The zeta function of a cubic surface over a finite field", Math Proc Cam Phil Soc 1967\. Your first equation then has $pN\+1$ solutions. 

Whenever the projectivization of your second equation is smooth, you get $p^3\+O(p^2\)$ solutions by general facts but the answer may not be as clean as the first one.

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Consider the equation ab² + cd² = bc² + da² over a finite field F_p, where p is an odd prime greater than 5. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the number of solutions to this equation?

A) The number of solutions is always exactly p³
B) The number of solutions is of the form p³ + αp² + β, where α and β are single-digit integers
C) The number of solutions is of the form p³ + αp + β, where α and β are single-digit integers
D) The number of solutions is of the form p⁴ + αp² + β, where α and β are single-digit integers

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The documentation states that the projectivization of the equation results in a smooth cubic surface for p > 5. The number of solutions to the projectivized equation is of the form N = p² + αp + β, where α and β are single-digit integers. The original equation then has pN + 1 solutions. Substituting N and simplifying:

pN + 1 = p(p² + αp + β) + 1 = p³ + αp² + βp + 1

This can be rewritten as p³ + αp² + (β+1)p, which is of the form p³ + α'p² + β', where α' and β' are still single-digit integers (α' = α and β' = β+1). Therefore, option B is correct.

Option A is incorrect as it doesn't account for the additional terms. Option C is incorrect because it underestimates the degree of p in the second term. Option D is incorrect as it overestimates the degree of p in the first term.

\#\#\# User: So I have two layers that I am adding into ArcMap. I know for a fact that when you added the first layer with Projected Coordinated System, the 2nd layer, which has a geographic coordinate system will project on the fly. My question is what would happen if the Geogrpahic coordinate System is added first. What would happen and what are the necessary steps to have them all fit properly in the same coordinate system ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The same thing would happen \- the projected CRS would be reprojected on the fly to the GCS.

With a new dataframe, the projection is set to the first layer added with a defined projection. All subsequent layers added, if different, will be reprojected to the dataframe's projection. Note a transformation may be required if the CRS datums differ, which should trip a warning message unless you've disabled that.

Steps for proper fit is going to depend on what data you have and what you're doing with it. Most likely you'll want a projected CRS for your dataframe and have the GCS data reprojected to that. There are tools to permanently reproject a dataset (note, there is a difference between DEFINE and PROJECT).

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: In ArcMap, when adding layers with different coordinate systems to a new dataframe, which of the following statements is correct?

A) If a layer with a Geographic Coordinate System (GCS) is added first, all subsequent layers will be reprojected to match the GCS.

B) The dataframe's projection is always set to the most recently added layer's coordinate system.

C) Layers with different coordinate systems cannot be added to the same dataframe without manual reprojection.

D) If a layer with a Projected Coordinate System (PCS) is added first, all subsequent layers, including those with GCS, will be reprojected on-the-fly to match the PCS.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. When a new dataframe is created in ArcMap, the projection is set to the first layer added with a defined projection. All subsequent layers added, if different, will be reprojected on-the-fly to match the dataframe's projection. This means that if a layer with a Projected Coordinate System (PCS) is added first, all subsequent layers, including those with a Geographic Coordinate System (GCS), will be reprojected on-the-fly to match the PCS of the dataframe.

Option A is incorrect because the behavior is the same regardless of whether a GCS or PCS layer is added first - the first layer's coordinate system becomes the dataframe's projection.

Option B is incorrect because the dataframe's projection is set by the first layer added, not the most recent.

Option C is incorrect because ArcMap can handle layers with different coordinate systems in the same dataframe through on-the-fly reprojection, without requiring manual reprojection.
